channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Europe’s Privacy Watchdogs Call for Changes to U.S. Data Transfer Deal
item.description: The region’s national regulators say the so-called Privacy Shield agreement does not sufficiently protect their citizens’ rights.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We believe there’s still work to do,” Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin, France’s data protection chief, who also heads a Pan-European regulatory privacy group, said on Wednesday.

item.title: E.U. Accuses Polish Government of Undermining Democracy
item.description: The European Parliament adopted a resolution urging the right-wing government in Warsaw to respect the decisions of a top court.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT
item.media:description: A demonstration in Warsaw last month against government moves that have paralyzed the nation’s Constitutional Tribunal.

item.title: Curfew Imposed After Deadly Clashes in Northern India
item.description: Three people were killed in Handwara and one in Kupwara, in Jammu and Kashmir State, as protesters clashed with soldiers and the police.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A funeral on Wednesday in Langate, in the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir, for a victim of the recent violence in the region.

item.title: E.U. Delays Decision on Requiring Visas of Americans and Canadians
item.description: The proposal is a response to delays in granting visa-free travel to citizens of Romania and Bulgaria, among other countries.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Passengers checking in at a Brussels airport in Zaventem last week. Americans and Canadians can generally travel to Europe without a visa, but that may change.

item.title: Sinosphere: Police Remove Bail Conditions on 5 Chinese Feminists Detained Last Year
item.description: However, the police said they were still investigating a case against them for “gathering a crowd to disturb public order,” said a lawyer for one of the women.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Zheng Churan, second from left, Li Tingting and Wei Tingting with Ms. Zheng’s lawyer, Chen Jinxue, left, next to a sign reading Haidian District Detention Center in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Rome Journal: 50 Years in a Cab: A Long, Winding Trip for One Driver, and His City
item.description: Over the decades, Alberto Tomassi has played tour guide, consoled abandoned wives, taken passengers to the emergency room — and had a front-row seat to a changing Rome.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alberto Tomassi, who has been a taxi driver in Rome for 50 years, with his eighth cab.

item.title: Greece Holds Activists as Migrants and Police Clash Anew at Macedonia Border
item.description: The second outbreak of skirmishes in three days came amid protests over border closings, which have left more than 12,000 stuck in a makeshift refugee camp.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A migrant sought safety after the Macedonian police used tear gas near the border town of Idomeni, Greece, on Wednesday.

item.title: Iranian Parliament Cancels Cash Subsidies to 24 Million People
item.description: Analysts said the action was a stick in the eye for President Hassan Rouhani, forcing him to figure out how to put the unpopular measure into effect.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Iranian Presidency, Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran in Tehran on Tuesday.

item.title: Inky the Octopus Escapes From a New Zealand Aquarium
item.description: Tracks suggest he slipped through a small gap at the top of his tank, scampered across the floor, slid down a 164-foot-long drainpipe and reached the ocean.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Inky the octopus at National Aquarium of New Zealand in Napier.

item.title: British Minister Admits Dating Woman in Sex Industry
item.description: John Whittingdale, who as culture minister oversees the nation’s news media, said tabloid newspapers knew about the woman’s occupation before he did.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: I.M.F. Warns of Economic Risk of British Exit From E.U.
item.description: The fund said a withdrawal from the bloc — or “Brexit” — would pose “major challenges for both the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe.”
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, Jean-Claude Juncker, the European Commission president; Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain; and Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, at a February meeting at the European Council in Brussels.

item.title: Documentary Stirs French as Officials Weigh a Labor Overhaul
item.description: François Ruffin’s film “Merci Patron!” takes on the luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton and its chief executive, Bernard Arnault.
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: François Ruffin, the director of “Merci Patron!” in Paris.

item.title: Dispatcher Playing With Cellphone Is Faulted in German Train Crash
item.description: He is expected to be charged with involuntary manslaughter, as well as violation of work rules, in the deadly collision of two trains in Bavaria on Feb. 9.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Peter Kneffel/Deutsche Presse-Agentur, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Eleven people died, and 80 were injured, some seriously, in a February train accident near Bad Aibling, Germany.

item.title: Judge in China Rules Gay Couple Cannot Marry
item.description: The pair, Sun Wenlin and Hu Mingliang, had sued a civil affairs bureau in Changsha after the office refused to grant them the right to marry.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and VANESSA PIAO
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sun Wenlin, left, and his partner, Hu Mingliang, in Changsha, China, in January. The case has galvanized some gay rights advocates in China.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Out of Africa
item.description: In a city in the Sahara, migrants assemble with hopes of escaping to a better life.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: Facing Impeachment Vote in Brazil, Dilma Rousseff Accuses Vice President of Conspiracy
item.description: Ms. Rousseff, Brazil’s president, responded to Vice President Michel Temer’s call for a government of national unity as the lower house prepared to vote.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Vice President Michel Temer of Brazil during a news conference in Brasília on Monday. He said on Tuesday that he was ready to assume the presidency “if destiny takes me to that position.”

item.title: ISIS Expands Reach Despite Military and Financial Setbacks
item.description: Officials say the Islamic State has lost thousands of fighters, millions of dollars and much territory, but the airstrikes have done little to stop the group’s expansion elsewhere.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG, HELENE COOPER and NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Airstrikes, like this one on Kobani, Syria, in 2014, have killed thousands of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Editorial: From Hiroshima to a Nuke-Free World
item.description: President Obama can be the first American president to stop at the war memorial when he travels to Japan next month.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Venezuela’s Court Deals Another Blow to Opposition Lawmakers
item.description: The Supreme Court’s rejection of a bill freeing about 120 political prisoners left some wondering whether lawmakers who are pushing for change have any real power.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:description: The opposition is exploring strategies against President Nicolás Maduro, from a popular recall vote to a change to the Constitution to cut his term short.

item.title: Effort to Impeach Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff Clears Congressional Panel
item.description: Supporters of the Brazilian leader are now scrambling ahead of a floor vote in the lower house of Parliament.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
